questions.text: Which of the following is/are true about Primary lymphedema? Lymphangiosarcoma may occur as a complication Associated with congenital lymphedema Onset between 2-35 years indicates lymphedema tarda Onset >35 years indicates praecox variety Prevalence is 2%, Choose the correct answer with respect to the above-given statements.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Options 1, 2 & 5 Primary lymphedema is which the cause is unknown; it is thought to be caused by ‘congenital lymphatic dysplasia’. Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare tumour that develops as a complication of long-standing (>10 years) lymphedema. Congenital Lymphoedema ( Nonne Milroy's disease) - < 2yrs old onset; sporadic, familial , It presents with non-pitting edema . Lymphedema Tarda – onset >35yrs old Lymphedema Praecox ( Letessier Meig’s disease) - 2 to 35 years onset; sporadic, familia At birth, 1 in 6000 persons will develop lymphoedema with an overall prevalence of 0.13–2%.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema : Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Primary lymphoedema Congenital It may involve a single lower extremity, multiple limbs, the genitalia, or the face. The edema typically develops before 2 years of age May be associated with specific hereditary syndromes (Turner syndrome, Milroy syndrome, Klippel-Trénaunay-Weber syndrome) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Accounting for 94% of cases. (Most Common) Lymphedema praecox is far more common in women, with the gender ratio favoring women 10:1. The onset is during childhood or the teenage years, and the swelling involves the foot and calf Tarda Uncommon, accounting for <10% of cases of primary lymphedema. The onset of edema is after 35 years of age

Extraedge:

Lymphedema is not curable, but the symptoms and long-term effects can be controlled with a combination of elastic compression stockings, limb elevation, pneumatic compression, and massage. Controlling the edema protects the skin and potentially prevents cellulitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old female who had undergone a radical mastectomy 10 years back now presents with swelling and oedema, which may occur in the residual breast or overlying skin following wide local excision and radiotherapy for mammary carcinoma is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angiosarcoma

Highyeild:

Classified as de novo, post-radiation, or arising in association with postmastectomy lymphedema. Angiosarcoma is now the preferred name. The average interval between MRM or radical mastectomy and the development of an angiosarcoma is 7 - 10 years. It is highly malignant, can metastasise rapidly, and presents with noticeable skin changes. 60% of women developing this cancer have a history of adjuvant radiation therapy. Clinical Features: Acute worsening of Edema The appearance of subcutaneous nodules with a propensity towards haemorrhage and ulceration Radiation-Induced Angiosarcoma (in the absence of previous radiation therapy or surgery) Reddish brown to purple raised rash within the radiation portals and on the skin of the breast. It may form a mass within the parenchyma of the breast Treatment Pre-operative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation) Associated with poor prognosis Forequarter amputation may be necessary to palliate ulcerative complications and advanced lymphedema.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Leiomyosarcoma is a malignant proliferation of smooth muscles of myometrium; it usually presents in postmenopausal females. Option B. Primary squamous cell carcinoma is a very rare malignancy of the breast that presents in the elderly group. Option C. Basal cell carcinoma is found in sun-exposed areas ( e.g., the body). Locally invasive and rarely metastasises.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presented with a lump in the breast and palpable axillary lymph nodes, for which she is now scheduled for a modified radical mastectomy. Which among the below is the most distressing complication after modified radical mastectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphedema Lymphedema (Because lymphedema can be associated with secondary skin changes and infection. Long-standing lymphedema can even become a malignancy known as Stevert Trewas syndrome).

Highyeild:

Mastectomy is indicated for large tumours (in relation to the size of the breast), multicentric disease, diffuse microcalcification on a mammogram indicative of DCIS, BRCA-positive cancers, local recurrence following BCS or the patient’s preference. It entails the removal of the entire breast tissue, including the skin over the tumour, the nipple-areola complex and the axillary tail. Complications of Mastectomy Wound infections: The majority are due to skin flap necrosis Lymphedema Seroma MC complication beneath skin flaps and axilla occurs in 30% of cases A catheter is retained until drainage is < 30 ml/day Injury to Long Thoracic (Motor) Nerve Seen in 10% of all cases. Result in a palsy of the Serratus anterior muscle (classical winged scapula) Injury to Thoracodorsal Nerve: Leads to palsy of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Redundant Axillary Fat Pad Axillary vein thrombosis may occur as a complication which is quite rare. Death is usually an uncommon complication

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Axillary vein thrombosis may occur as a complication which is quite rare. Option C: Seroma MC complication beneath skin flaps and axilla occurs in 30% of cases The catheter is retained until drainage is < 30 ml/day Option D: Death is usually an uncommon complication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has undergone surgery for her knee, for which she has been immobile for more than 4 months. Now she presents with swelling of the lower limb, oedema and lymphadenitis. The chronically lymphoedematous limb is predisposed to all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marjolin’s ulcer Marjolin’s ulcer is slow growing locally malignant lesion, a very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma occurring in an unstable scar of long duration, burns and chronic wounds. Marjolin’s ulcer is avascular and has poor prognosis.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Pathology : Result of an inability of the existing lymphatic system to accommodate the protein and fluid entering the interstitial compartment at the tissue level. First Stage - Soft pitting oedema (impaired lymphatic drainage results in protein-rich fluid accumulation in the interstitial compartment) Second Stage - Non pitting and Spongy consistency (the clinical condition is further exacerbated by the accumulation of fibroblasts, adipocytes, and, perhaps most important, macrophages in the affected tissues, which culminates in a local inflammatory response) Third Stage - Lymphostatic Elephantiasis (excessive subcutaneous fibrosis and scarring with associated severe skin change). Edema is irreversible at this stage. Unlike other types of oedema, lymphoedema characteristically involves the foot. The contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the Sub malleolar depressions, A ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, The toes appear ‘square’ because of confinement of footwear The skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Stemmer’s sign) . Lymphoedema usually spreads proximally to knee level & less commonly affects the whole leg. Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin (dermatophytosis) and nails (onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease. Lymphangiosarcoma can develop in any long-standing lymphedema Ulceration is unusual, except in the presence of chronic venous insufficiency

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - Thickening of the skin due to subcutaneous fibrosis, which leads to dermal thickening and hyperkeratosis, for which unable to pinch on the dorsum of skin (stemmer’s sign) Option B - Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin(dermatophytosis), nails(onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae and warts are seen in advanced diseases. Option D - Lymphangiosarcoma can develop in any long-standing lymphedema but usually takes too long to manifest (>20yrs).

questions.text: A neonate presents with lower limb swelling and edema at birth. Lymphoscintigraphy findings show a failure of initial lymphatic absorption (functional aplasia), the affected gene in this condition is the FLT-4 gene and family history is significant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nonne- Milroy's disease A familial version of congenital lymphedema is known as Nonne-Milroy disease. Onset before 1st year of life, Edema is typically present at birth. It can involve a single lower extremity, multiple limbs, genitalia or face. More likely to be bilateral and involve the whole leg. FMS- like tyrosine kinase 4(FLT-4) gene is affected, whereas Milroy’s disease is congenital lymphedema that usually presents as non-pitting edema < 2 years of age.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Vascular endothelial growth factor C(VEGF-C) gene is affected. Lymphoscintigraphy findings show reduced initial uptake with tortuous lymphatic tracts and evidence of rerouting. Option C . Collagen and calcium-binding EGF domain-containing protein 1 (CCBE1), Homolog of drosophila FAT tumour suppressor 4 (FAT4) genes, are affected. Microcephaly, unusual face and lymphoedema affecting all four limbs. Findings show abnormal lymph drainage in all four limbs and the thoracic duct. Option D . Gata- binding protein 2 (GATA-2) gene is affected. Myelodysplasia (Emberger syndrome) Warts, recurrent viral and/or bacterial infections. Predisposition to several cancers. Findings show hypoplasia of lymphatics.

questions.text: 40 years old male known case of lymphedema for 10 years, now presents with ulceration, non-healing bruises and raised purple-red nodules. The doctor is suspicious of malignancy. Which among the below is/are associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Ulceration, non-healing bruises and raised purple-red nodules should lead to suspicion of malignancy. The conditions can develop secondary to lymphedema like Lymphangiosarcoma, Kaposi sarcoma, squamous cell carcinoma etc .

Highyeild:

Lymphangiosarcoma : Classified as de novo, post-radiation, or arising in association with postmastectomy lymphedema. Angiosarcoma is now the preferred name. The average interval between MRM or radical mastectomy and the development of an angiosarcoma is 7 - 10 years. It is highly malignant and can metastasise very rapidly, and it presents with obvious skin changes. 60% of women developing this cancer have a history of adjuvant radiation therapy. Clinical Features: Acute worsening of Edema The appearance of sub-cutaneous nodules with a propensity towards haemorrhage and ulceration Radiation-Induced Angiosarcoma (in the absence of previous radiation therapy or surgery) Reddish brown to purple raised rash within the radiation portals and on the skin of the breast It may form a mass within the parenchyma of the breast Treatment: Pre-operative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation) Associated with poor prognosis Forequarter amputation may be necessary to palliate ulcerative complications and advanced lymphedema. Kaposi’s Sarcoma : Kaposi’s sarcoma is a malignant, proliferative tumor of vascular endothelial cells, which was first described in elderly Jewish men but is now most commonly associated with immune compromise after transplantation or HIV infection. There appears to be a causal link with infection by human herpesvirus 8. Kaposi’s sarcoma usually starts as a red-brown, indurated, plaque-like skin lesion that becomes nodular and then ulcerates. Treatment: Radiotherapy Squamous Cell Carcinoma : SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinising cells of the epidermis or its appendages. It arises from the stratum basalis of the epidermis and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10 Associated with UVR, chronic inflammation, immunosuppression and chemical carcinogens Management: Surgical Excision

Extraedge:

questions.text: In her sixth decade, this patient presented with rapid onset of swelling of the right leg. On further investigation, she was found to have locally advanced bladder carcinoma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphedema Lymphoedema developing for the first time after 50 years should prompt a thorough search for underlying (pelvic, genitalia) malignancy. It is worth noting that, in such patients, lymphoedema often commences proximally in the thigh rather than distally. There is obstruction at the level of the aortoiliac or inguinal nodes. The patient may benefit from a lymphatic bypass operation if associated with distal dilatation. Other patients have distal obliteration as well.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema : Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Pathology: Result of an inability of the existing lymphatic system to accommodate the protein and fluid entering the interstitial compartment at the tissue level. First Stage - Soft pitting oedem (impaired lymphatic drainage results in protein-rich fluid accumulation in the interstitial compartment) Second Stage - Non-pitting and Spongy consistency (the clinical condition is further exacerbated by the accumulation of fibroblasts, adipocytes, and, perhaps most important, macrophages in the affected tissues, which culminates in a local inflammatory response) Third Stage - Lymphostatic Elephantiasis (excessive subcutaneous fibrosis and scarring with associated severe skin change). Oedema is irreversible at this stage. Aetiological classification of lymphoedema: Primary lymphoedema Congenital (onset <2 years old): sporadic; familial (Nonne–Milroy’s disease) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Tarda (onset after 35 years old) Secondary lymphoedema A parasitic infection (filariasis) Fungal infection (tinea pedis) Exposure to foreign body material (silica particles) Primary malignancy Metastatic spread to lymph nodes Radiotherapy to lymph nodes Surgical excision of lymph nodes Trauma (particularly degloving injuries) Superficial thrombophlebitis Deep venous thrombosis. Diagnosis : Unlike other types of oedema, lymphoedema characteristically involves the foot. The contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the Sub malleolar depressions, A ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, The toes appear ‘square’ because of the confinement of footwear and The skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Stemmer’s sign) . Lymphoedema usually spreads proximally to knee level & less commonly affects the whole leg. Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin (dermatophytosis) and nails (onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease. Ulceration is unusual, except in the presence of chronic venous insufficiency Treatment : General Therapeutic Measures : Appropriate Antibiotics Maintenance of ideal body weight Elevation and Compression Garments : The ideal compression garment is custom-fitted and delivers 30 to 60 mm Hg pressures. Limb Elevation at night Avoid standing for prolonged periods Complex Decongestive Physical Therapy Compression Pump Therapy (Pneumatic Compression therapy) Drug Therapy - Benzopyrones Molecular Lymphangiogenesis Operative Treatment : Reconstructive - should be considered for those patients with proximal (either primary or secondary) obstruction of the extremity lymphatic circulation with preserved, dilated lymphatics peripheral to the obstruction. Excisional - only viable option for patients without residual lymphatics of adequate size for reconstructive procedures. For patients with recalcitrant stage II and early stage III lymphedema in whom the edema is moderate and the skin is relatively healthy, an excisional procedure that removes a large segment of the lymphedematous subcutaneous tissues and the overlying skin is the procedure of choice.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Swelling, usually of the whole leg, due to iliofemoral venous obstruction. Venous skin changes, secondary varicose veins on the leg and collateral veins on the lower abdominal wall. Venous claudication may be present. Option C. There may be an obvious predisposing factor, such as recent surgery . The classical signs of pain and redness may be absent. Option D. Rare; Present at birth or develops in early childhood. Comprises an abnormal lateral venous complex, capillary naevus, bony abnormalities, hypoplasia of deep veins and limb lengthening. Lymphatic abnormalities often coexist. Klippel- trenaunay's syndrome is characterised by congenital malformation or absence of lymphatics. It is not characterised by swelling or lymphedema developing in 6th decade in patients.

Extraedge:

Lymphedema is not curable, but the symptoms and long-term effects can be controlled with a combination of elastic compression stockings, limb elevation, pneumatic compression, and massage. Controlling the edema protects the skin and potentially prevents cellulitis

questions.text: All of the following are causes of secondary lymphedema except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nonne- Milroy's disease Nonne- Milroy's disease is congenital; it is Primary lymphedema. It presents as non-pitting edema due to congenital obstruction in lymphatic drainage.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration. Primary lymphoedema Congenital (onset <2 years old): sporadic; familial (Nonne–Milroy’s disease) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Tarda (onset after 35 years old) Secondary Lymphedema Secondary lymphedema is far more common than primary lymphedema. Secondary lymphedema develops as a result of lymphatic obstruction or disruption. Axillary node dissection leading to lymphedema of the arm is the most common cause of secondary lymphedema. Other causes of secondary lymphedema include radiation therapy, trauma, deep venous thrombosis, infection, and malignancy. Globally, filariasis (an infection caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori) and environmental exposure to minerals in volcanic soil resulting in podoconiosis in barefoot populations are the most common causes of secondary lymphedema.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B & D: Radiotherapy and Chronic Venous Insufficiency are secondary causes of secondary lymphedema. Option C: Axillary node dissection leading to lymphedema of the arm is the most common cause of secondary lymphedema.

There is usually no precipitating cause but recurrent tumour should be excluded because neoplastic infiltration of the axilla can cause arm swelling due to both lymphatic and venous blockage.
